utterances: So when people fish, you know, be careful with your bait.
And when you're using earthworms in your compost pile, you should be more careful in your compost pile.
And so there's been - I think the awareness is starting to improve through education and outreach that people need to be a bit more careful with earthworm.
All right.
We're be earthworm wary.
Thank you very much, Professor Groffman, for taking time to be with us.
Oh, it was a pleasure to be here.
Peter M.
Groffman, senior scientist at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies in Millbrook, New York.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
And now, the TALK OF THE NATION Opinion Page.
You couldn't lose money betting on Helen Mirren for best actress last week.
In fact, betting on any Brit in that category is pretty safe, as Judi Dench and Kate Winslet were both nominated as well.
In an op-ed in Sunday Currents section of yesterday's Philadelphia Inquirer, Jonathan Last asks the question that might rankle every American actor: What do British actors have that U.S.
film actors, generally speaking, do not?
Consider the evidence.
Here's a scene-chilling Kenneth Branagh as Henry V.
(Soundbite of movie, ""Henry V"")
(as Henry V) And gentleman in England now a-bed shall think themselves accursed they were not here, and hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks that fought with us upon St. Crispin's Day.
(Soundbite of crowd cheering)
Articulate, eloquent.
Well, how about the Americans?
(Soundbite of movie, ""A Streetcar Named Desire"")
(as Stanley Kowalski) Hey, Stella.
The great Marlon Brando, of course, chewing up Tennessee Williams.
Jonathan Last is the online editor for the Weekly Standard.
He joins us here in Studio 3A.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thanks for having me.
And, of course, this modest proposal begs some input from you.
Are the Brits generally better actors?
Miles better?
Why?
Or why not?
E-mail us talk@npr.org.
And Jonathan, first of all, there's plenty of great American actors.
You name a few in your op-ed.
I name a few, I can think of others.
I hope this doesn't rankle people too, too much.
These are always meant to be conversation starters, I think, and not enders.
I'm a voracious consumer popular culture myself.
I embrace everything from ""Veronica Mars"" and ""Buffy, the Vampire Slayer"" to ""Hamlet"" and ""Midsummer Night's Dream"".
One can appreciate and really enjoy the gifts of American actors, I think, while still also understanding that when you're really are bloodless and ruthless about it, the Brits are just better.
Not merely just better in your opinion, you say, make up their - your list of top 10 actors of all time - we're talking about the world of movies, so in the past 100 years or so.
And you say you don't have room for many Americans there.
Yeah.
I think you probably don't.

If you were to make a quick and dirty list of the top 10 British male actors - film actors of the last, you know, 50, 60 years or so - you would have to have, I think, John Gielgud and Laurence Olivier, Kenneth Branagh, whom we heard, probably Richard Harrison, Michael Gambon.
I would also throw in Ian McKellen, probably Alec Guinness, Jeremy Irons, Richard Burton, David Niven.
And it leaves out so many people.
It leaves out the great Peter Sellers of the world.
It leaves Ray Fiennes and Colin Firth, who are, you know, very fine young actors.
Bob Hoskins.
Bob Hoskins is fantastic, and Albert Finney.
Really, the list can go on.
Of course, you don't want people to get too upset.
Lists are, by very definition, exclusionary.
They are always going to be great people who were left off.
When you look at that, that great classical list, I think it's very hard to find many American actors - if any - who really would be able to crack that top 10.
Brando is certainly one of the greats, Robert De Niro, Jack Nicholson, contemporary great actors whoâ€¦
Al Pacino.
Yeah.
At various points North Korea has claimed it's been developing satellites.

That's what it said about the one and only long-range missile test it carried out eight years ago and at that point North Korea launched a Taepo Dong-1 missile over Japan, but its third stage is believed to have exploded over the Pacific.

As for the range of this missile, the Defense Intelligence Agency last year estimated that with two stages it might be able to reach parts of the western United States and with three stages it could cover the entire U.S.

But practically speaking, because this rocket is untested, it probably has a range of a few thousand miles, making it capable of reaching Guam and possibly the western most part of the Aleutian Islands in Alaska.
And why so much concern about this possible test and I guess a question of timing, why now?
Well first, we don't know what North Korea's intentions are, whether it's simply a test or could be carrying something dangerous.
Under pressure from the U.S., North Korea has been observing a missile test moratorium since 1999 and it made separate and similar commitments to Japan in 2002.
Japan was concerned because that earlier test, the one that exploded, flew over its territory.
So a launch now would break commitments to both the United States and Japan.
South Korea is also concerned.
The timing of the preparations is a bit odd actually because the former South Korean President, Kim Dae-Jung, is planning to visit North Korea soon to see its leader Kim Jung Il.
This is a commemoration of a landmark summit the two leaders had in 2000.
So if there was a launch, it would probably destroy the possibility of this semi-summit meeting.
Also Australia and New Zealand have appealed to North Korea not to launch.
And the United States has been hoping to entice North Korea back to the six-party nuclear talks, which have been stalled since September, so a missile launch now would make that even more remote.
And those six-party talks, why have they stalled?
Well, the talks include South Korea, Japan, Russia and China, but they're really about the U.S.
and North Korea.
And Washington and Pyongyang have been talking past each other for months.
The United States has put North Korea under additional financial stress in recent months and Pyongyang used that as an excuse not to go back to the negotiating table.
Recently the North Koreans invited the key U.S.
diplomat in this process, Assistant Secretary of State Christopher Hill, to go to Pyongyang for direct talks but the Bush administration said no to that.
So the negotiation process is dead.
North Korea is presumed to be reprocessing more and more plutonium and now it appears to be on the verge of breaking its missile launch moratorium.

Mike before we let you go, just quickly, I'd like you to help us read between the lines when we listen to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice when she says that any such tests would be an act of provocation.
What does that exactly mean, when you hear something like that from the Secretary of State?
Well, it obviously means that the United States will have to respond in some fashion and the response at this point seems to be focused on discussions at the U.N.
Security Council and possible additional economic sanctions that might be imposed on North Korea.
Thank you, Mike.
You're welcome.
NPR's Mike Shuster.
As Scott and I just mentioned, housing prices are plummeting.
The Standard and Poor's Case-Shiller Index is out today.
It shows a more than 18 percent decline for the end of 2008 in 20 areas around the country.
Joining us now is the Case in the Case-Shiller index.
Karl Case, welcome to the program.
Good to be here, Madeleine.
Well, tell us first, flesh that out for me, the headline from your report out today.
Well, the headline is more of the same.
You've got every market declining, some markets declining more than others.
Two basic groups of markets.
One is the Phoenix, Las Vegas, San Francisco, Miami Sunbelt, which are - have a tremendous number of foreclosure options.
They count for about 54 percent, actually, of all the foreclosure options in those four states - Arizona, Nevada, California and Florida.
The rest of the country is not in free fall.
It has - house prices are falling, but at a rate of, like Boston is down 15 percent over a period of three years.
And as you say this is the worst showing in the 21 years you've been doing this.
Oh, I mean, we've never seen anything like this, ever.
I mean, it's a dramatic decline.
It does come on the heels - you have to keep this in mind - of a tremendous runup.
In fact, in all of our cities, there's only one city that has prices below their 2000 levels.
I mean, so we had a huge runup in many parts of the market, literally a 200 percent increase.
Housing prices tripled, particularly at the low end as credit expanded in the middle of the decade.
So it's following on a tremendous expansion, and we're down to the point where still all of our cities are above - substantially above where they were at the beginning of the decade.
So...
So I guess you could be arguing that they're just coming down to realistic levels.
Yeah, I could be arguing that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
